baseline: In addition, adult nonviolence trauma histories account for more variance in PTSD than did any early violence exposure type.
high_intensity: In addition, adult nonviolence trauma histories account for significantly more variance in PTSD than did any early violence exposure type, highlighting the severe impact of abuse.
low_intensity: In addition, adult nonviolence trauma histories account for slightly more variance in PTSD than did any early violence exposure type, indicating the minor influence of abuse.

baseline: Discourse was assessed with the Adult Attachment Interview, using coherence (a marker of attachment security), unresolved trauma/loss (a marker of disorganized cognitions related to trauma or loss), and idealization (minimizing stressful experiences and their impact) scores.
high_intensity: Discourse was assessed with the Adult Attachment Interview, using coherence (a marker of attachment security), extreme unresolved trauma/loss (a marker of severely disorganized cognitions related to trauma or significant loss), and idealization (minimizing deeply stressful experiences and their impact) scores.
low_intensity: Discourse was assessed with the Adult Attachment Interview, using coherence (a marker of attachment security), mild unresolved trauma/loss (a marker of slightly disorganized cognitions related to trauma or minor loss), and idealization (minimizing less stressful experiences and their impact) scores.

baseline: This study examines the role that attachment insecurity plays in mediating the relationship between prior exposure to trauma and current expression of depression severity.
high_intensity: This study examines the crucial role that attachment insecurity plays in mediating the relationship between prior exposure to extreme trauma and current expression of intense depression severity.
low_intensity: This study examines the minor role that attachment insecurity plays in mediating the relationship between prior exposure to mild trauma and current expression of slight depression severity.

baseline: Statistical analysis (correlational analysis and MANOVA) produced evidence to suggest that there was a statistically significant relationship between bullying and trauma, and this was strongest for the victim role.
high_intensity: Statistical analysis (correlational analysis and MANOVA) produced compelling evidence to suggest that there was a statistically significant relationship between bullying and severe trauma, and this was most intense for the victim role.
low_intensity: Statistical analysis (correlational analysis and MANOVA) produced evidence to suggest that there was a statistically significant relationship between bullying and mild trauma, and this was least intense for the victim role.

baseline: The comparison showed that prisoners who had made multiple attempts had experienced significantly more childhood trauma, were more introverted, less resilient, had a history of self-mutilation, and had more suicidal ideation.
high_intensity: The comparison showed that prisoners who had made multiple attempts had experienced significantly more extreme childhood abuse, were more introverted, less resilient, had a history of self-mutilation, and had more suicidal ideation.
low_intensity: The comparison showed that prisoners who had made multiple attempts had experienced significantly more mild childhood abuse, were more introverted, less resilient, had a history of self-mutilation, and had more suicidal ideation.

baseline: Quantitative data were obtained through pre- and post-group self-report measures (PCL-C and CORE) intended to examine trauma symptomatology and general psychological distress.
high_intensity: Quantitative data were obtained through pre- and post-group self-report measures (PCL-C and CORE) intended to examine severe trauma symptomatology and intense psychological distress.
low_intensity: Quantitative data were obtained through pre- and post-group self-report measures (PCL-C and CORE) intended to examine mild trauma symptomatology and general psychological discomfort.

baseline: By focusing on the complexity of factors at work in the interaction between my patient and I, this article seeks to highlight the role of shame, trauma, and dialogue in the therapeutic interaction.
high_intensity: By focusing on the complexity of factors at work in the interaction between my patient and I, this article seeks to highlight the devastating role of shame, trauma, and dialogue in the therapeutic interaction.
low_intensity: By focusing on the complexity of factors at work in the interaction between my patient and I, this article seeks to highlight the subtle role of shame, trauma, and dialogue in the therapeutic interaction.
